title: 110_hr2910
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Education Tuition Support Act of 2007" or the "VETS Act of 2007." Congress finds that the defense of the United States is paramount. Since 2003, over 1.3 million Armed Forces members served in Iraq or Afghanistan. Veterans sacrifice their lives, families, and education to serve. In 2005, 500,000 veterans claimed education benefits. Many Armed Forces members rely on financial aid and Montgomery GI Bill benefits for college. The 6 percent interest rate cap on debts for active duty members is not applied to Federal student loans. Returning deployed members are forced to start repaying private student loans soon after returning. Members of the Armed Forces transitioning from combat to education face challenges, including bureaucracy when reenrolling. Colleges are not required to accommodate active duty students, leading to difficulties with tuition reimbursement and reenrollment requirements. Symptoms of PTSD and other injuries may take up to a year to manifest, highlighting the need for support for returning service members. Members of the Armed Forces transitioning from combat to education face challenges with reenrollment and tuition reimbursement. This Act aims to provide a 13-month transition period for them to reenroll in education programs and begin repaying student loans, with a 6 percent interest rate cap. The Act aims to provide a 13-month transition period for Armed Forces members to reenroll in education programs with a 6 percent interest rate cap on student loans. Providers of education programs must offer reasonable accommodations to students who discontinue due to deployment. SEC. 707 of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act provides tuition, reenrollment, and student loan relief for postsecondary students called to military service. Whenever a servicemember is called to military service and withdraws from an institution of higher education, the institution must refund tuition and fees for the portion of education not completed and offer the opportunity to reenroll with the same academic status. Additionally, repayment of loans can be deferred for servicemembers called to military service. When a servicemember is called to military service and takes a leave of absence from college, the provider of student loans must adjust repayment terms. If the servicemember reenrolls within 13 months, the repayment date is extended. If not, repayment begins after the 13-month period. The text discusses the definitions of key terms related to student loans, including Federal financial aid programs and institutions of higher education. The text exempts student debts from creditor protection based on income level for servicemembers enrolled in higher education on a full-time basis. A clerical amendment is also made to the table of contents in the Act. The amendments provide tuition, reenrollment, and student loan relief for postsecondary students called to military service, effective for periods of military service after the enactment of this section.
